subject: RE: [junit] Re: black box or white box?
msgSnippet: ... Sorry about that, I thought I turned that off.... ... I m sorry. I guess my definition of white-box testing is testing private and protected members of a
messageBody:
> From: ilja.preuss@... [mailto:ilja.preuss@...]
>
> (I don't like to top-post, but as these mails arrived in
> html-format, it is much easier to do so...)

Sorry about that, I thought I turned that off....


> The example given, although an example of white box testing,
> doesn't require to use anything private. It just requires you
> to take a look at the implementation to find out what the
> interesting test conditions look like.
>
> Why shouldn't you use JUnit in this case?

I'm sorry.

I guess my definition of white-box testing is testing private
and protected members of a class.

I use JUnit to test all public access. If one implementation
of an interface fails, I apply the same test against all
implementations--to ensure that it doesn't happen again.
